DM11:15am

esterday I read Dan McCrum's article on Sirius Minerals. As a shareholder, I like to think I know quite a lot about the project and have to say his report was both inaccurate and sensationally negative. It was typical of a news reporter writing an article simply in order to sell newspapers.
You can be very sure that I will no longer be buying your newspaper for this very reason.

Forester The problem with SXX is tat everything has gone swimmingly so far and the SP assumes that everything will continue go swimmingly. I have parked on sidelines for now.
DM11:20am

The inference here seems to be that Sirius had misled investors by implying that the agreement was for 1.5mt of offtake from day one. We find this line of argument somewhat perplexing given offtake agreements for any mining operation need to be scaled with a delay to the production ramp up to allow for headroom in case production misses expectation

LK Hyman @DM I never understood why ADM required anonymity in the first place.
Pharma @Mouselet, if "K" is taken to mean Kelvin, a Google search of "Kelvin" and "Middlesbrough" reveals a superior candidate for the Darwin Awards.
DM11:21am

Do go have a look at the announcements. The 2013 one came first, half a million tonnes from initial production

11:22 am
DM11:22am

The Agreement is for the sale of at least 500,000 tonnes per annum of polyhalite for an initial period of 5 years with a possible renewal for a further 5 years.

DM11:23am

Then the upgrade

LK Hyman @Pharma Anyone can buy a share but you need a pair of rigger boots and a hard hat to know about E&P.
DM11:23am

The initial Agreement, for the supply of polyhalite from the York Potash Project ("the Project"), was announced on 21 January 2014. It was for 500,000 tonnes per annum of polyhalite for a five year period, from commencement of production, with a possible renewal for a further five years. The Agreement counterparty also had the option to take up to an additional 500,000 tonnes per annum.

The revised Agreement will see the base amount of polyhalite supplied tripled to 1.5 million tonnes per annum. The initial contract term is extended from five years to seven years, with possible extension options for two additional five year periods.

11:23 am

The base amount tripled. The company probably could have done a better job explaining the ramp up there

DM11:31am

Cineworld has delivered a very good H1 with p/f Ebitda +14.1% driven by a 4.9%
increase in p/f admissions to 158.9m customers. H2 has started strongly. The
integration of Regal is progressing well (but it’s early days). Management continues
to expect the full year outcome to be ‘in line’ with its expectations.

LK Hyman @Upaswell It isn't "financing" Sirius; it's merely saying it'll buy some of their output if it's produced.
Mouselet [ plugs 'Lying for Money' again ]
DM11:32am

Integration good so far

11:31 am
DM11:32am

UK was weaker
due to the weather and the football. All revenue lines performed well. Cineworld has
enjoyed a great start to its ownership of Regal with a surprisingly strong film slate (
Black Panther, Avengers: Infinity War) driving admissions. H2 is not such a strong slate
but has nevertheless started well, helped by Mission Impossible, Mamma Mia and the
Incredibles. Q4 will depend on the next instalment or Fantastic Beasts and the reboot
of Mary Poppins (especially in the UK). The film slate over the next few years is strong
helped by a strong Disney slate. US average ticket prices rose by +4.6%.

DM11:32am

(@Mouslet Dan Davies book Lying for Money is excellent, and funny)

Pharma Our local Vue cinema charges £5 per ticket, any film, any time. The local Odeons charge £10-15. Anyone know if this is across the country? Seems an odd think to do in the summer holidays.
anonymous254 @AM, cheers. Believe mining is only sector (on UK markets that is) that requires what is in effect independent commercial due diligence on the underlying asset to be carried out and included in the offering docs? Special protection I guess for prospective shareholders given the difficulty in assessing what is true?
Mouselet err, yes, I've read it, it's really good, that's why I was plugging it
alewis2005 morning all

David Evershed Our local Vue does not charge a flat £5 but full prices.

Critics of the Regal deal felt the deal was too big for Cineworld and that the company had taken on too much debt. The level of borrowing is high at 3.8 times earnings but more announcements like today’s may begin to win over the sceptics.

“The underlying business is cash generative and investors will be looking for the debt position to have improved by the year end.

Underlying profits were up from €7.3m to €34.8m although the market seems to be focussing on a decline in profits during the third quarter of 13% to €193.4m.

DM11:43am

Yet the company still guides to 10 per cent earnings growth

RobDev can't wait for the next crisis, i'm prepared this time
Ethelred will unwind a bit over next two months
DM11:43am

EBITDA growth

11:43 am
DM11:43am

I'll let UBS explain:

DM11:44am

Company has maintained guidance for at least 10% EBITA growth for the full year. The company expects the good weather in key source markets to represent a potential headwind in Q4 – limiting outperformance vs. guidance. Company guides for a €35m negative FX impact for FY18.

DM11:44am

On a divisional basis Source Markets underlying EBITA came in at €42.5m (vs. UBSe €60m) with good results in Central and Nordics offset by lower margins in the UK and France. Hotels €74.7m (UBSe €83m) and Cruises at €90.9m (UBSe €87m) driven by TUI Cruises and Marella. Destination Experiences reported €15.3m (UBSe €17m). In Sales and Marketing we note +4% growth in summer 2018 bookings with 86% of the programme sold (broadly in line with last year). Average occupancy in Hotels was 80% (vs. 75% 3Q17) with flat pricing. In cruises ADR improved by +1.6% y/y.

johnwigglesworth Tritax Big Box (BBOX) weak despite on-track results. Any brokers have a comment, please?

Kind of odd after Thomas Cook guided down last week, which is probably part of the reaction today

DM11:46am

Following the update, we continue with our expectations of an 11% growth in underlying EBITA but with a €35m drag from FX rather than a €10m previously. We therefore lower our headline EBITA and PBT by c€25m to €1,118m and €1,068m (EPS: €1.2) respectively.

Tritax requested

Tritax Big Box Reit PLC (BBOX:LSE): Last: 152.60, down 2.4 (-1.55%), High: 155.00, Low: 152.55, Volume: 587.76k
A. M. (@Provender: you're welcome. enjoy)
11:48 am
DM11:48am

Liberum, holders

DM11:48am

H1 results confirm a modest half year for Tritax with NAV +3% to 146p, in line with of our forecast and the dividend +5%, also in line and fully covered by earnings. Management continue to deploy capital following the recent ~£160m raise with a focus on forward funded development and current commitments expected to take the LTV back to the target 35%. Tritax’s long let income, backed by significant tenant investment and a strong structural tailwind is attractive at a marginal discount to industrial peers, but less exposure to the faster growing South is now more visible. The shares trade on a CY18E P/NAV of 1.03x vs the UK Real Estate sector on 0.90x and yield 4.3%.

DM11:49am

Industrial boxes a great business

adatherton Shore : Forex slippage is a tiny part of revenue but a huge part of profit. Wonder if they have a dedicated forex team, surprisingly weakly resourced area in many corporates, given the impact.

Pharma @David, yes, had a quick scan of ones in the Northwest and seems there is quite a variation.
DM11:52am

And RBS wasn't the only desk to suffer in the big sell off last month

DM11:52am

But what caught the eye was ABN Amro's fixed income team

11:52 am
DM11:53am

Trouble Brewing in Italy

DM11:53am

The Italian banking situation has deteriorated in the last four weeks…
 Banca Carige and Banco BPM both show early signs of potential volatility
 And even the best political scenario will not improve the fiscal situation in Italy
 We reduce our exposure to Italy, even removing our UniCredit overweight

Pharma Doesn't the LSE have some sort of Italian bond business?
DM11:53am

In terms of the weaker banks, the issues are numerous, but in particular, Banca Carige is a
large concern. On July 22, Banca Carige was asked by the European Central Bank (ECB) to
submit a plan to raise capital or consider a merger, details of the request can be found here.
In recent months the chairman and a number of board members have left the struggling Italian
lender and now a legal case has also arisen.

wayneJ Morning Dan
11:53 am
DM11:53am

The problem is that the bank specifically needs to increase its total capital this year, ideally
with the issuance of Tier 2 debt in order to meet an overall capital requirement of 13.125%.
We cannot see it being able to issue Tier 2 securities without an ECB approval to the bank. It
a bit of a vicious cycle between, with the ECB wishing capital to be raised, but investors
needing an ECB approved plan to invest.

wayneJ Late logging on. Usually Bryce is warming up about now.
DM11:54am

Banca Carige could bring significant volatility across Italian markets for periods after
summer. As stated, it will be tough for the bank to issue the Tier 2 debt needed by the ECB,
and merger talks (as we saw with Veneto Banca and Banca Popolare di Vicenza) are chaotic
in Italy.

TheDubliner Any grey on G4S?
DM11:54am

(Morning Wayne, nice of you to join us)

11:54 am
DM11:55am

What is more, investors already have shown concerns for the Italian banking sector and
isolated cases show that the conditions recently in Italy are very weak

DM11:56am

Big sell off in the alphabetised lower tier debt stuff this year in Italy. They were too expensive in January, but keep an ear to the rumblings

G4S PLC (GFS:LSE): Last: 257.10, down 24.9 (-8.83%), High: 280.90, Low: 255.30, Volume: 5.66m

Should we be shocked by a 9 per cent move in support services?

11:57 am
DM11:58am

Feels kind of normal these days

wayneJ Presumably the current Ryan Air strikes are positive for travel operators with their own airplanes; I was trying to fly somewhere today for the weekend and was surprised how tight seat availability is this weekend
DM11:58am

The big picture conclusion is very few people have a good sense of how to forecast revenues and costs in this sector, managements included

DM11:59am

possibly a problem in a business where you have to bid for contracts on the basis of such estimates, but what do I know

11:59 am
DM11:59am

Barclays:

DM11:59am

Organic sales growth in the half was below our forecast but it had been unusually hard to forecast due to the hardware sales from the Walmart contract. Growth improved as the half progressed, going from a 2% decline in Q1 to 2.8% growth in Q2.

DM11:59am

Divisionally, most segments were broadly in-line with our estimates in a period that was hard to forecast due to the restructuring of the segments. Americas was better but Cash Solutions segment was worse with profits being depressed by the revenue contraction due to the lower hardware sales being worse than we forecast profit and investment in the Cash360 business.

11:59 am
DM12:00pm

Despite the half coming in slightly weaker than expected, guidance for the full year is unchanged. Management’s confidence in hitting full year consensus of £489m of EBITA (Barclays £490m) will be supported by the new Cash360 contracts that have been secured, an improvement in contract retention and cost saving initiatives.

wayneJ @pharma - does a candidate have to be alive for the Darwins? PS - the articles from that Google search have damaged my brain for the rest of the day
Blank canvas Thank you DM for everything today.
Mouselet Thank you
Mouselet Cash360 strikes me as a reasonable thing to do but an investment with obviously finite lifetime
wayneJ Guys - aren't you going to challenge Dan to go as long as Bryce? At least to 12:10 if not 12:20?
DM12:02pm

CMC markets goes with the old saw:

DM12:02pm

Support services provider G4S which along with its sector peers has had a pretty rough ride in recent years, has seen its profits come in at £212m, down from £219m a year ago. Revenues were slightly higher with the company announcing £700m in new contract wins in the first half, as the company left its guidance unchanged for the rest of the year. With the shares near six month highs investors appear to be using this decline in profits as an excuse to take some profits.

Pharma @WayneJ, sorry - I blame Mouselet for his original question.
